arcs.title: The Zoo Catalyst: When One Level Forced a New Mario 64 Engine
arcs.summary: Early in development, one ambitious level—the Zoo—ran so badly on real Nintendo 64 hardware that Kaze realized adding “more content” wasn’t the work. If RTYI was going to feel like a real game on a real console, he had to rebuild the foundations that Mario 64 normally gets away with.
arcs.narrative_value: This is the cleanest origin story for a global audience: the dream collides with a physical limit, and frustration becomes a multi‑year craft project. It directly answers the film’s central question: he deconstructs a classic because the classic can’t carry the ambition.
arcs.challenge: Build larger, denser worlds than Mario 64—while keeping them playable on original N64 hardware (not just emulators).
arcs.process: Kaze treats performance as a creative enabler: he profiles slow scenes, finds “invisible” costs hiding in mundane assumptions (like how coins are drawn), and celebrates small percentage wins because on N64 those wins buy entire new kinds of scenes.
arcs.outcome: RTYI stops being “a mod with new levels” and becomes, in practice, a new engine that can support richer worlds—because it was forced to become one.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: The zoo is actually the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64.
key_quotes.context: Single sentence that makes the Zoo the inciting incident for years of foundational work.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Look at this. This is an N64 game.
key_quotes.context: A simple, audience-friendly payoff line: the ambition is visible and physical.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space… Every coin here is a sprite.
key_quotes.context: A concrete example of retro constraints: tiny rendering assumptions become project-defining decisions.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: We found like a 10–15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy.
key_quotes.context: Late-stage optimization as drama: a breakthrough that only matters because the project is so close to the edge.

interview_questions.question: Take me back to the first moment the Zoo told you, ‘content isn’t the problem—the foundation is.’ What did you see on screen, and what did it feel like?
interview_questions.context: Turns an engineering pivot into an emotional origin story with a clear before/after.
evidence: May 2023: Kaze says the Zoo is the reason he started optimizing Mario 64 (20230520).

interview_questions.question: For someone who’s never coded: what’s one performance fix you’re proud of because it’s absurdly small—yet it changed what you were allowed to build?
interview_questions.context: Connects invisible work to visible payoff without jargon.
evidence: Oct 2023: coins changed to screen-space sprites; 10–15% gain (20231028).

interview_questions.question: Biobak, when Kaze shows you a performance win, what changes emotionally? Do you feel ‘freedom,’ or do you feel ‘new rules’?
interview_questions.context: Lets a non-programmer translate performance into creative permission and constraint.
evidence: Performance work enables denser visuals; art/tech negotiation visible throughout 2023 (e.g., 20230618, 20231028).

arcs.title: Reality Check: The N64 Won’t Forgive You (and Emulators Will Lie)
arcs.summary: RTYI can “work” in an emulator—then crash instantly on real hardware from failure modes that feel impossible in modern development. Over time, Kaze’s workflow becomes a cycle of pride, humiliation, and adaptation: test on console, hit a hardware-only wall, and learn the machine’s actual rules.
arcs.narrative_value: Makes the Nintendo 64 feel like a character: strict, physical, and non-negotiable. It’s also a perfect accessibility bridge—viewers don’t need to understand code to understand ‘it crashes on the real console.’
arcs.challenge: Hardware-only crashes and hard platform limits repeatedly invalidate progress that looked fine in emulators.
arcs.process: Kaze validates on real N64, learns “the language” of retro failures (compiler scheduling, coordinate bounds), and upgrades his debugging approach (hardware-accurate tools; a tight deploy-to-console loop).
arcs.outcome: A console-first mindset becomes policy: reality is defined by the N64, and emulator support is negotiated—not assumed.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: The compiler decided… to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0.
key_quotes.context: An explainable ‘invisible monster’: code that looks safe becomes unsafe because of platform rules.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: NEMU crashes here just like N64 would? That’s crazy. I could probably debug a lot of N64 crashes in NEMU then. Oh my god, that is going to save me so much time.
key_quotes.context: A turning point where tooling changes the pace of progress.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.
key_quotes.context: A blunt, audience-readable constraint that forces art and design changes.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Playing this on Unreal Hardware is like half the point.
key_quotes.context: Late-stage reaffirmation: authenticity isn’t nostalgia, it’s the mission.

interview_questions.question: What was the first crash on real hardware that made you think, ‘we might not ship this on an N64’?
interview_questions.context: Establishes the N64 as antagonist and sets real stakes early.
evidence: July 2023: delay-slot divide-by-zero (20230716).
Sept 2023: N64/accurate emu crashes reveal multiple level issues (20230902).

interview_questions.question: How do you explain ‘emulators lie’ to a non-technical viewer without blaming emulator authors? What’s the emotional cost of trusting the wrong ‘truth’?
interview_questions.context: Turns compatibility into a human story about trust and uncertainty.
evidence: Sept–Oct 2023: hardware-only failures + stricter limits (20230902, 20231014).
Aug 2025: ‘Unreal Hardware’ stance (20250803).

interview_questions.question: What’s one art/design compromise you had to demand because of a hard crash rule—something that felt unfair until you accepted it?
interview_questions.context: Connects console limits to visible changes (scale, backgrounds, distance).
evidence: Oct 2023: out-of-range object crash constraints shape presentation decisions (20231014).

arcs.title: “Fuck Mario 64’s Collision”: Rebuilding Movement for Fairness and Determinism
arcs.summary: Mid-project, Kaze decides Mario 64’s collision—the invisible rules that decide what you can stand on—is sabotaging the entire game. He rewrites it so players stop getting punished by unpredictable geometry, then keeps pushing until the system becomes faster, more stable, and less “random.”
arcs.narrative_value: This is the purest “deconstruct the classic” arc. Even viewers who don’t game understand the motive: when the rules feel unfair, you either accept it—or you rebuild the rules.
arcs.challenge: Vanilla collision creates unpredictable movement and edge cases that become unacceptable in more ambitious levels; later, sub-frame timing can make outcomes feel random and untestable.
arcs.process: Kaze replaces patchwork fixes with a new stepping/collision approach, then iterates toward determinism (“no hidden randomness”). In late stage, he finishes a faster global collision structure (BVH) and frames it as a release from regression-heavy engine churn.
arcs.outcome: Movement becomes more trustworthy and measurable, but integration is costly: older content breaks, crashes appear in unexpected places, and the project absorbs months of foundational risk to protect player trust.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable.
key_quotes.context: A definitive line that proves RTYI is no longer ‘just new levels.’

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: If there's a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I'll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I'll remove it.
key_quotes.context: His ethics of “respecting” the classic while refusing accidental unfairness.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.
key_quotes.context: Turns an engineering rewrite into a moral/player-trust stance.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Oh my god, that’s going to feel so good. I can actually just make the game and the game will get done.
key_quotes.context: The emotional release when a deep collision milestone finally stops the project from breaking itself.

interview_questions.question: What was the specific moment you decided Mario 64’s collision was ‘unusable’—what happened to Mario on screen that crossed the line for you?
interview_questions.context: Anchors a deep technical rewrite in a concrete, visual frustration anyone can picture.
evidence: Feb 2024: collision rewrite begins; ‘unusable’ framing (20240210).

interview_questions.question: You’re willing to change things people love (like certain classic tricks). How do you decide what’s ‘fun tech’ versus what breaks player trust?
interview_questions.context: Directly interrogates respectful vs new, and speedrunner expectations vs general audience fairness.
evidence: Feb 2024: policy on intentional vs accidental bugs (20240210).
Jun 2026: anti-randomness movement stance (20250622).

interview_questions.question: By the time collision BVH was done, you sounded relieved. What kind of exhaustion builds up when foundational systems keep causing regressions?
interview_questions.context: Draws out the human cost of engine work and why this project took years.
evidence: Aug 2025: BVH completion framed as end of regression churn (20250827).

arcs.title: The Island That Remembers: Turning a Hub into the Game’s Soul
arcs.summary: What starts as a debate about what the overworld should even be turns into RTYI’s defining ambition: an island that evolves, gates progress in physical, story-driven ways, and permanently changes when you help it. Over years, Kaze pushes a single promise: if you can see it, you should eventually reach it—and the world should explain why you can’t yet.
arcs.narrative_value: This is RTYI’s biggest “new game” claim for a mainstream audience. The overworld is not a menu; it’s a living place with memory, which emotionally answers “why rebuild Mario 64 at all?”
arcs.challenge: Make a huge overworld feel explorable and alive without becoming empty, confusing, or arbitrarily locked—while still running within N64 memory/performance limits.
arcs.process: Kaze and Biobak negotiate the overworld’s purpose, then build systems that make exploration meaningful (secrets, gates, coin uses, persistent world changes). He designs cinematic, readable gates like the lighthouse revealing the ghost ship, then later hits the late-stage reality: the overworld runs out of RAM and must be split into many sub-areas without breaking the illusion of one island.
arcs.outcome: A clear overworld identity emerges—change over time, fair barriers, landmark-led navigation—along with a late-game engineering plan to preserve that identity under hard memory limits.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I've had some arguments with Biobak… and I think we've come to a pretty good agreement.
key_quotes.context: Rare admission of creative conflict—and resolution—around the project’s core pillar.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: The overworld needs to be full of secrets… That’s gonna make or break the game. Guaranteed.
key_quotes.context: A thesis line that can become a documentary refrain.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: What if the ship is here, but it's like a shadowy fog, and you have to go into the lighthouse... point the light at the ship... Now you can actually enter it. I think that's a banger idea.
key_quotes.context: A cinematic gate concept that any viewer can understand without UI jargon.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I want the player to save the world and then be like, yep, this is the world now. You saved it.
key_quotes.context: The emotional design goal: a world that visibly remembers you.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: The thing actually is that we ran out of RAM in the overworld.
key_quotes.context: Late-act twist: the ‘biggest level’ hits the oldest possible limit.

interview_questions.question: Tell the story of the overworld argument with Biobak. What were you each trying to protect—and what finally made the shared direction click?
interview_questions.context: Gives interpersonal stakes to a design pillar that shapes the whole film.
evidence: July 2023: Kaze mentions arguments and agreement (20230709).

interview_questions.question: Why are you obsessed with barriers feeling ‘genuine’ instead of ‘the game saying no’? What’s a barrier in your life that shaped that instinct?
interview_questions.context: Invites a personal, non-technical motivation behind a very technical design constraint.
evidence: Feb 2025 onward: multiple ‘fair barrier’ design statements (e.g., lighthouse gate 20250223; barriers-as-real principle 20250402).

interview_questions.question: Describe the moment you could run a full loop around the island—then later the moment you realized it didn’t fit in memory. What did that emotional swing do to you?
interview_questions.context: A perfect late-film beat: pride → setback → adaptation.
evidence: Feb 2026: overworld out of RAM (20260201).

interview_questions.question: Biobak, how do you make ‘before vs after’ world changes readable on N64-era visuals—so players feel the island is healing, not just ‘different’?
interview_questions.context: Pulls art direction into the ‘world remembers’ thesis, not as decoration but as storytelling.
evidence: Apr–Jun 2025: ‘world saved should look saved’ philosophy + ongoing overworld densifying (20250419, 20250630).

arcs.title: Patience Budget and ‘No Slop’: The Readability Crusade
arcs.summary: From the first level onward, Kaze designs as if players are one frustration away from quitting—especially because it’s a free fan-made game and people will leave fast. Across years of playtests, he repeatedly rebuilds missions and navigation so the game communicates through environment and flow instead of confusing puzzles, surprise camera behavior, or chores disguised as challenge.
arcs.narrative_value: This is the project’s accessibility spine. It explains RTYI’s taste and ethics in plain language: respect the player’s time, don’t confuse them, don’t sand the game into ‘slop’ either.
arcs.challenge: Teach new movement and guide exploration without handholding, ugly UI markers, or punishing confusion—on a camera and control model that can easily create accidental inputs.
arcs.process: Kaze prototypes tutorials that require the correct action (not just reading text), adopts a predictable-camera rule rooted in human reaction time, studies outside playthroughs, and keeps redrawing the line between “friction that gives purpose” and “bullshit that makes people quit.”
arcs.outcome: A consistent doctrine emerges: clear forward momentum, natural guidance, and carefully chosen difficulty—tested against real player behavior, not developer pride.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: You have to be very careful with the text you put, because players start out with some amount of patience left for your game… but for a ROM hack, you can’t really go over your patience budget.
key_quotes.context: A documentary-ready explanation of why onboarding matters more for fan projects.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: If you make the camera rotate without the player being able to predict it, you’re always going to have the player do a direction they don’t intend, because there is human reaction time of like 200 milliseconds in-game time.
key_quotes.context: Human-centered design logic that non-coders immediately understand.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: The overall conclusion is the player really needs to be guided to Star 1 a lot more.
key_quotes.context: Playtest evidence forces a redesign: clarity is earned, not assumed.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: There comes a point at which you reduce friction so much that you lose the game's purpose and soul. And it just turns into slop. And I don't want to make it slop.
key_quotes.context: His modern-vs-classic calibration in one line—central to ‘respectful yet new.’

interview_questions.question: When did you learn the idea of a ‘patience budget’? Was there a past project where you watched players bounce and realized it was your fault?
interview_questions.context: Gives personal backstory for a philosophy that shapes every level.
evidence: Apr 2023: patience budget + tutorial approach (20230413).

interview_questions.question: Can you tell one specific story where playtest footage made you delete something you’d already built—because it was confusing, not because it was broken?
interview_questions.context: Turns usability into an emotional, cinematic ‘kill your darlings’ moment.
evidence: Apr 2024: area rebuilt after watching playtesters (20240420).
Dec 2024: Star 1 guidance conclusion after testers quit (20241207).

interview_questions.question: Define ‘slop’ with examples. What are three ‘helpful’ features you refused because they would have made the game worse?
interview_questions.context: Makes an abstract value concrete for a general audience.
evidence: Nov–Dec 2025: ‘slop’ framing and friction philosophy (20251116, 20251222).

arcs.title: Finale Identity Crisis: From Space Arcade to Healing a Sick Yoshi
arcs.summary: The final course begins as a loud ‘space arcade’ spectacle—then collapses under an uncomfortable truth: it isn’t fun and it doesn’t feel like a real place. Kaze scraps and rebuilds the finale as a Shy Guy space colony, then solves the biggest tonal problem of all: the final boss shouldn’t be something you kill, but something you save.
arcs.narrative_value: A complete, high-emotion creative pivot late in the timeline: sunk cost, honesty, and taste. It’s also a universally understandable moral design choice—how do you make a climax that feels right for a world where Yoshis are friends?
arcs.challenge: Build a coherent final level that feels like a place (not minigames), and a climactic boss that fits Yoshi’s Island tone without becoming grotesque or emotionally wrong.
arcs.process: Kaze rejects the ‘arcade’ framing, rebuilds around colony “placeness,” then iterates boss concepts until landing on a healing loop (remove corruption so the Yoshi returns to green). He tunes visuals and tone based on feedback, pulling back from body-horror reads.
arcs.outcome: The finale’s identity becomes clearer and more emotionally legible: a society under stress, and a final act framed as rescue rather than conquest—pending ongoing tuning/polish.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I don’t want this game to turn into W64 where it’s like, oh you like 3D platformers? Fuck you. Here’s Pac-Man.
key_quotes.context: A line in the sand: RTYI won’t become a collection of unrelated gimmicks.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: We made the important realization that the idea we had for this level is terrible. And we’re going to do something better.
key_quotes.context: Rare on-camera accountability; the pivot moment is explicit.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: That’s a bang idea. I think we’ll do that.
key_quotes.context: The moment the final boss becomes a rescue story rather than a kill story.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: It’s not a hentai monster, it’s just a nice Yoshi who’s just sick and needs your help.
key_quotes.context: Tone management in plain language; protects audience interpretation.

interview_questions.question: What was the exact play moment where ‘space arcade’ stopped feeling exciting and started feeling like a lie?
interview_questions.context: Turns a big pivot into a concrete, reenactable memory.
evidence: Dec 2024: space arcade declared terrible; retheme to colony (20241229).

interview_questions.question: What does ‘placeness’ mean to you in a platformer? Why did colony infrastructure (homes, water, propaganda) solve a design problem better than arcade machines?
interview_questions.context: Helps a non-technical audience understand why theme is a tool, not decoration.
evidence: Dec 2024–Jan 2025: colony rebuild rationale (20241229, 20250105).

interview_questions.question: Kaze & Zeina: whose idea was the ‘sick Yoshi’ framing, and what did each of you want the player to feel—sadness, hope, relief?
interview_questions.context: Centers their partnership in the project’s emotional climax.
evidence: Jan–Feb 2025: healing boss concept and tone clarification (20250112, 20250202).

interview_questions.question: How do you decide where the tone line is—what’s ‘too much’ for a Mario-adjacent world, even if it would be dramatic?
interview_questions.context: Lets Kaze articulate restraint as respect, not censorship.
evidence: Feb 2025: explicit tone clarification to avoid disgusting/body-horror reads (20250202).

arcs.title: Audio Eats the Cartridge: The Sound Engine Rewrite and the 64MB Squeeze
arcs.summary: RTYI hits an old-school limit with modern consequences: the cartridge size and audio pipeline. Music and sound don’t just decorate the game—they dominate ROM space, and the original Mario 64 sound engine becomes a stability and performance liability. Kaze eventually rips the audio foundation out, runs multi-day console tests to catch rare bugs, and fights toward a clean, crackle-free soundscape.
arcs.narrative_value: A rare documentary-friendly tech arc where the stakes are audible and intuitive: storage runs out, sound breaks immersion, and the only way forward is deep ownership of the foundation. It also gives Badub a natural role tied to constraints, not just inspiration.
arcs.challenge: Keep RTYI within real N64 limits while supporting a large soundtrack, avoiding audio-induced instability, and fixing bugs that only appear after days of runtime on real hardware.
arcs.process: Kaze audits ROM usage (music dominates), weighs streamed vs sequenced tradeoffs, then rewrites major parts of the sound engine for performance and debuggability. He validates with extreme soak tests (days of real-console runtime) and iterates until audible defects (crackling) are eliminated.
arcs.outcome: Audio becomes a custom, release-critical pillar: more stable, more performant, and more capable—while remaining one of the last high-risk systems near the finish line.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Sound data table here—this is 35.6 megabytes of just music. Two-thirds of the ROM is just music.
key_quotes.context: A shocking, concrete statistic a general audience instantly understands.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I’m trying to fix Mario 64’s sound engine. It sucks. I’m kind of just ripping it out, making my own.
key_quotes.context: Reframes RTYI from ‘modding’ to replacing core console-era systems.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: My N64 is running over there… it’s gonna be running for six and a half days, because I need footage of a bug that only happens after six and a half days.
key_quotes.context: An endurance beat that’s absurd, visual, and human.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I made the most important fix in history yesterday. The audio crackling is gone.
key_quotes.context: A late-stage, high-relief milestone—polish as survival.

interview_questions.question: What did it feel like to realize the cartridge wasn’t filling up with ‘the game’—it was filling up with music?
interview_questions.context: Turns a budget audit into an emotional turning point about tradeoffs.
evidence: Oct 2023: music dominates ROM (20231007).

interview_questions.question: Tell the story of the six-and-a-half-day bug like a thriller. What did you hear, and how did you keep going when the test itself took a week?
interview_questions.context: Makes invisible QA feel like dramatic persistence.
evidence: Apr 2025: six-and-a-half-day console run described (20250415).

interview_questions.question: Badub, how do constraints like storage and engine format change what you write? What do you do differently when ‘beautiful’ and ‘shippable’ aren’t the same thing?
interview_questions.context: Gives the composer a constraint-driven narrative role, not just a musical one.
evidence: Oct 2023: streamed music size tension (20231007).
Apr–Jun 2025: sound engine rewrite becomes production-critical (20250415, 20250604).

arcs.title: Walking the Nintendo Line: Free Release, Open Source Strategy, and ‘0% Nintendo Code’
arcs.summary: Because RTYI is built on a beloved franchise, every creative decision also lives under legal gravity. Kaze draws non-negotiable boundaries—no selling the game, no physical cartridges—and later escalates to an audacious long-term goal: rewrite until the project is effectively ‘0% Nintendo code,’ with contingency plans for a dual build (Mario / no-Mario) and an engine-only release.
arcs.narrative_value: External stakes that any global viewer understands: the work can’t be sold normally, could be targeted, and forces strategic release choices. It also reframes refactors as self-preservation and authorship, not perfectionism.
arcs.challenge: Finish and preserve the project in a legal gray zone, support collaborators ethically, and reduce takedown risk without killing public momentum.
arcs.process: Kaze plans open-source timing strategically, refuses the obvious monetization routes, and progressively replaces inherited code—partly for quality, partly for ownership and defensibility. He develops explicit takedown contingencies (dual builds; original-IP escape hatch).
arcs.outcome: A pragmatic posture: RTYI remains free and cautious, but is increasingly engineered to survive (and potentially transform) if legal pressure escalates.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: We should probably delay open sourcing the game a little from the initial release, just so Nintendo doesn’t instantly take it down.
key_quotes.context: Shows open source as strategy under risk, not just ideology.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I'm not gonna make a physical cartridge because if I do I will get sued to shit.
key_quotes.context: A bright-line rule audiences instantly understand.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Eventually we’ll be at 0% Mario 64 code.
key_quotes.context: A mission statement that fuses legality, authorship, and engineering ambition.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: So we can release both a version with Mario and a version without Mario. So that when Nintendo, on like week 1, is on our door and is like, take this down, we can be like, fine, but there's another. Fuck you.
key_quotes.context: Defiant, cinematic contingency planning—high documentary value.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I'm going to finish the RTYI engine, hopefully get to 0% Nintendo code, and release just the engine with Mario in a flat field to the public.
key_quotes.context: Concrete plan that turns ‘engine’ into a verifiable legacy object.

interview_questions.question: What’s your personal definition of the line you won’t cross—what would make RTYI feel like ‘selling Nintendo’s game’ instead of building your own work?
interview_questions.context: Keeps legal talk grounded in ethics and motivation, not legal jargon.
evidence: Apr 2023: open-source timing as takedown mitigation (20230422).
Sep 2023: no physical carts (20230909).

interview_questions.question: Explain ‘0% Nintendo code’ to a non-programmer. What are you protecting: the project’s survival, your integrity, or your ability to sleep at night?
interview_questions.context: Translates a technical/legal goal into human stakes.
evidence: Aug 2025: 0% code mission statement (20250818).
Dec 2025: engine-only release plan (20251223).

interview_questions.question: If you ever had to ship a ‘no-Mario’ build, what would you fight to keep because it’s the soul of the game—and what would you gladly change because it was always just borrowed clothing?
interview_questions.context: Forces articulation of ‘respectful yet new’ beyond IP logos.
evidence: Oct 2025: dual-build contingency described (20251005).

interview_questions.question: Badub, how do you think about ownership and compensation in a project that must be free? What would ‘fair’ look like if the plan ever shifts toward an original commercial release?
interview_questions.context: Brings collaborator perspective into a legal/economic arc often dominated by the lead developer.
evidence: Sep 2023: merch/royalty brainstorming around legal limits (20230909).
Dec 2025–Jan 2026: talk of lawyer/rights (20251223, 20260103).

arcs.title: The Partnership Pipeline: Kaze & Zeina’s Co‑Creation—and Becoming Parents Mid‑Build
arcs.summary: RTYI is not just a solo technical feat; it’s built inside a marriage where Zeina’s animation and art often determine whether moments land emotionally. As the project grows, the couple also becomes parents, turning development into a negotiation between craft, time, and a new family rhythm.
arcs.narrative_value: This arc provides the documentary’s emotional center: dependency, patience, and shared standards. It’s also a rare look at creative partnership under pressure—one person builds systems, the other gives them soul, and both have to live with the consequences.
arcs.challenge: Coordinate a production where key sequences depend on Zeina’s animation deliveries, while also adjusting to pregnancy, birth, and the day-to-day unpredictability of parenting.
arcs.process: They review animation choices together, Kaze schedules implementation around Zeina’s deliverables, and he changes difficulty when her play experience reveals blind spots. Parenthood becomes a timeline marker that reshapes energy, cadence, and priorities.
arcs.outcome: A visible “handoff rhythm” emerges—code skeleton first, then animation/presentation polish—while the family milestone recontextualizes what “finishing” means.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I still also need to do the end cutscene, but I was waiting for the animations for Zeina first.
key_quotes.context: A simple line that reveals real pipeline dependency inside a small team.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: My bar is usually: when I watch the player and it’s painful to watch them, I need to make it easier.
key_quotes.context: Empathy as a design metric, tied directly to watching someone he loves struggle.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: I watched Zeina play it and she would have had to restart the game 15 times.
key_quotes.context: A vivid anecdote that makes difficulty tuning personal, not abstract.

key_quotes.speaker: Zeina
key_quotes.quote: She’s named after a friend of mine that passed away when I was 12 years old.

arcs.title: Building in Public Isn’t Free: Harassment, Algorithms, and ‘Three Jobs’
arcs.summary: Streaming makes RTYI collaborative and accountable—but it also turns development into performance under pressure. Kaze navigates harassment, relentless release-date demands, and a creator economy that rewards jokes over deep work, all while juggling a full-time job and family responsibilities.
arcs.narrative_value: Explains the real-world forces that shape a multi-year fan project: money, attention, cruelty, and burnout. It makes timeline slips emotionally legible even for viewers who don’t care about Mario 64.
arcs.challenge: Sustain long-form development when public visibility brings harassment and when income depends on platform incentives that often punish serious work.
arcs.process: Kaze sets boundaries (“when it’s done”), adapts channel strategy to protect reach, and talks candidly about opportunity cost. He reframes criticism as potentially useful while still acknowledging the emotional damage of being watched and judged live.
arcs.outcome: A fragile equilibrium: the project survives publicly, but the mental and financial load becomes part of the work—not separate from it.

arcs.title: When Great Art Hits Hardware: Biobak’s Vision, Kaze’s Integration, and the Price of ‘Vibe’
arcs.summary: Biobak delivers beautiful concepts—Star Select mood pieces, major level reworks, even a new Mario model—and Kaze’s job is to make them real inside N64 constraints. The story repeats: it looks great in modern tools, then real implementation reveals seams, crashes, and performance limits that force clever compromises.
arcs.narrative_value: This is collaboration made visible. It’s also the best way to show non-technical viewers that retro constraints aren’t abstract: they change what art can be, and they create real team negotiation.
arcs.challenge: Translate high-quality modern art into a stable, performant N64 build—where materials, coordinates, draw order, and memory have hard ceilings.
arcs.process: Kaze rebuilds menu systems to match Biobak’s mockups, hunts crashes caused by old geometry assumptions, fixes render-layer and transparency issues after imports, and validates performance on real hardware. The collaboration becomes a pipeline: deliver → integrate → discover constraint → iterate together.
arcs.outcome: RTYI’s presentation becomes a signature: “not just a mod.” The cost is constant integration labor and a growing set of art/engine rules that keep the project shippable.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze
key_quotes.quote: Imagine entering this level for the first time… you think it’s just going to be a normal game and then you see this… that’s going to be so impressive. It’s finally done.
key_quotes.context: Kaze treats UI/presentation as emotional storytelling, not decoration.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze

key_quotes.context: A perfect illustration of ‘looks fine’ becoming ‘hardware says no.’

key_quotes.context: Debugging as integration: the crash isn’t random, it’s old assumptions colliding with new art.

key_quotes.speaker: Kaze

key_quotes.context: The payoff moment when art ambition survives the real machine.

key_quotes.context: A counterintuitive win that reframes ‘better art’ as also ‘smarter budget.’
